===Camp and guilty pleasures=== Chuck Kleinhans states that the difference between a guilty pleasure and a cult film can be as simple as the number of fans; David Church raises the question of how many people it takes to form a cult following, especially now that home video makes fans difficult to count.<ref name=cineaste /> As these cult films become more popular, they can bring varied responses from fans that depend on different interpretations, such as [[camp (style)|camp]], irony, genuine affection, or combinations thereof. Earnest fans, who recognize and accept the film's faults, can make minor celebrities of the film's cast,<ref>{{cite web|last=Adams|first=Sam|title="Best Worst Movie": The Cult of the Truly Bad Film|url=http://www.salon.com/2010/05/14/best_worst_movie/|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=2013-06-16|date=2010-05-14}}</ref> though the benefits are not always clear.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Paris|first=Robyn|title=How 'The Room' Turned Me Into a Cult Movie 'Star'|journal=[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]]|date=2012-04-30|url=http://www.backstage.com/advice-for-actors/first-person/how-the-room-turned-me-into-a-cult-movie-star/|accessdate=2013-06-16}}</ref> Cult film stars known for their camp can inject subtle parody or signal when films should not be taken seriously.<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Justin|editor1-first=Kate|editor1-last=Egan|editor2-first=Sarah|editor2-last=Thomas|title=Cult Film Stardom: Offbeat Attractions and Processes of Cultification|year=2012|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=978-0-230-29369-4|pages=110–111|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h7xn-AWOj88C&pg=PA110|chapter=Vincent Price and Cult Performance: the Case of Witchfinder General}}</ref> Campy actors can also provide comic book supervillains for serious, artistic-minded films. This can draw fan acclaim and obsession more readily than subtle, [[method acting|method]]-inspired acting.<ref>{{cite book|last=Simpson|first=Philip L.|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35780-0|pages=90–91|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lAIMzLLh9nUC&pg=PA90|editor-first=Bob|editor-last=Batchelor|chapter=Lector for President}}</ref> Mark Chalon Smith of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' says technical faults may be forgiven if a film makes up for them in other areas, such as camp or transgressive content. Smith states that the early films of [[John Waters (director born 1946)|John Waters]] are amateurish and less influential than claimed, but Waters' outrageous vision cements his place in cult cinema.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Mark Chalon|title=FILM: 'Pink Flamingos': Cult of Bad Taste|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-04-02/news/ol-91_1_pink-flamingos|accessdate=2013-06-16|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1992-04-02}}</ref> Films such as ''[[Myra Breckinridge (film)|Myra Breckinridge]]'' (1970) and ''[[Beyond the Valley of the Dolls]]'' (1970) can experience critical reappraisal later, once their camp excess and avant-garde filmmaking are better accepted,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Diffrient|first=David Scott|title="Hard to Handle": Camp Criticism, Trash-Film Reception, and the Transgressive Pleasures of Myra Breckinridge|journal=[[Cinema Journal]]|year=2013|volume=52|issue=2|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/cinema_journal/v052/52.2.diffrient.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-29|url-access=subscription |via=[[Project MUSE]]}}</ref> and films that are initially dismissed as frivolous are often reassessed as campy.<ref name=beach /> Films that intentionally try to appeal to fans of camp may end up alienating them, as the films become perceived as trying too hard or not authentic.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jackson|first=Jeffrey C.|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35780-0|page=48|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lAIMzLLh9nUC&pg=PA48|editor-last=Batchelor|editor-first=Bob|chapter=The Godfather of Cult}}</ref>
===Nostalgia=== According to academic Brigid Cherry, [[nostalgia]] "is a strong element of certain kinds of cult appeal."<ref name=borrowings /> When [[Veoh]] added many cult films to their site, they cited nostalgia as a factor for their popularity.<ref>{{cite web|last=Termen|first=Amanda|title=It's the Site of the Living Dead, as Cult Films Hit Web|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1025_3-6047466.html|work=[[CNET]]|accessdate=2013-08-01|date=2006-03-08}}</ref> Academic I. Q. Hunter describes cult films as "New Hollywood ''in extremis''" and a form of nostalgia for that period. Ernest Mathijs instead states that cult films use nostalgia as a form of resistance against progress and capitalistic ideas of a time-based economy.<ref name=cineaste /> By virtue of the time travel plot, ''Back to the Future'' permits nostalgia for both the 1950s and 1980s. Many members of its nostalgic cult following are too young to have been alive during those periods, which Emma Pett interprets as fondness for retro aesthetics, nostalgia for when they saw the film rather than when it was released, and looking to the past to find a better time period.<ref name=nostalgia /> Similarly, films directed by [[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]] have taken hold in midnight movie venues, trading off of nostalgia for the 1980s and an ironic appreciation for their optimism.<ref>{{cite news|last=Beale|first=Lewis|title=John Hughes Versus the Vampires: The Dilemma of the Midnight Movie|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/19/movies/19beal.html|accessdate=2013-08-01|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2006-06-19}}</ref> Mathijs and Sexton describe ''[[Grease (film)|Grease]]'' (1978) as a film nostalgic about an imagined past that has acquired a nostalgic cult following. Other cult films, such as ''[[Streets of Fire]]'' (1984), create a new fictional world based on nostalgic views of the past.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|title=Cult Cinema|year=2011|publisher=[[Wiley & Sons]]|isbn=978-1-4443-9643-0|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uPtuaV7IAt0C&pg=PT217|accessdate=2013-08-01|chapter=Cult Cinema and Music}}</ref> Cult films may also subvert nostalgia, such as ''The Big Lebowski'', which introduces many nostalgic elements and then reveals them as fake and hollow.<ref>{{cite news|last=Boudreau|first=Emily|title=The History and Meaning of The Dude's Abiding|url=http://www.michigandaily.com/content/big-lebowski-retrospective-notebook|accessdate=2013-08-01|newspaper=[[Michigan Daily]]|date=2010-09-08}}</ref> Nathan Lee of the ''[[New York Sun]]'' identifies the retro aesthetic and nostalgic pastiche in films such as ''[[Donnie Darko]]'' as factors in its popularity among midnight movie crowds.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Nathan|title=How 'Donnie Darko' Refused to Die|url=http://www.nysun.com/arts/how-donnie-darko-refused-to-die/134/|accessdate=2013-08-01|newspaper=[[New York Sun]]|date=2004-07-25}}</ref>
===Midnight movies=== Author Tomas Crowder-Taraborrelli describes [[midnight movie]]s as a reaction against the political and cultural conservatism in America,<ref name=midnight />{{rp|27}} and Joan Hawkins identifies the movement as running the gamut from anarchist to [[Libertarianism|libertarian]], united in their anti-establishment attitude and punk aesthetic.<ref name=hawkins />{{rp|223}} These films are resistant to simple categorization and are defined by the fanaticism and ritualistic behaviors of their audiences. Midnight movies require a night life and an audience willing to invest themselves actively.<ref name=midnight>{{cite book|last=Crowder-Taraborrelli|first=Tomas F.|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream: How the Fringe Became Mainstream, Volume 1|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35781-7|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jqd92sX1hAoC&pg=PA27|editor-first=Bob|editor-last=Batchelor|chapter=Midnight Movies and the Phenomenon of the Cult Film}}</ref>{{rp|27–30}} Hawkins states that these films took a rather bleak point of view due to the living conditions of the artists and the economic prospects of the 1970s. Like the surrealists and dadaists, they not only satirically attacked society but also the very structure of film – a counter-cinema that deconstructs narrative and traditional processes.<ref name=hawkins />{{rp|224–226}} In the late 1980s and 1990s, midnight movies transitioned from underground showings to home video viewings; eventually, a desire for community brought a resurgence, and ''The Big Lebowski'' kick-started a new generation. Demographics shifted, and more hip and mainstream audiences were drawn to them. Although studios expressed skepticism, large audiences were drawn to box office flops, such as ''[[Donnie Darko]]'' (2001), ''[[The Warriors (film)|The Warriors]]'' (1979) and ''[[Office Space]]'' (1999).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Palopoli|first=Steve|title=Cult Rapture|journal=[[Metro Silicon Valley]]|date=2003-09-17|url=http://www.metroactive.com/papers/cruz/09.17.03/cult-0338.html|accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> Modern midnight movies retain their popularity and have been strongly diverging from mainstream films shown at midnight. Mainstream cinemas, eager to disassociate themselves from negative associations and increase profits, have begun abandoning midnight screenings. Although classic midnight movies have dropped off in popularity, they still bring reliable crowds.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Olsen|first1=Mark|last2=Kaufman|first2=Amy|title=Moviegoing at the Midnight Hour|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/may/04/entertainment/la-et-mn-ca-new-midnight-movies-20130505|accessdate=2013-07-28|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2013-05-04}}</ref>
===Art and exploitation=== Although seemingly at odds with each other, [[art film|art]] and [[exploitation film]]s are frequently treated as equal and interchangeable in cult fandom, listed alongside each other and described in similar terms: their ability to provoke a response. The most exploitative aspects of art films are thus played up and their academic recognition ignored.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hawkins|first=Joan|title=Cutting Edge: Art-Horror and the Horrific Avant-garde|year=2000|publisher=[[University of Minnesota Press]]|location=Minneapolis|isbn=0-8166-3413-0|pages=3–4|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68whFPvH5VEC&pg=PA3|chapter=Sleaze-Mania, Euro-trash, and High Art}}</ref> This flattening of culture follows the popularity of [[post-structuralism]], which rejects a hierarchy of artistic merit and equates exploitation and art.<ref name=betz />{{rp|202–203}} Mathijs and Sexton state that although cult films are not synonymous with exploitation, as is occasionally assumed, this is a key component; they write that exploitation, which exists on the fringes of the mainstream and deals with [[taboo]] subjects, is well-suited for cult followings.<ref name=exploitation>{{cite book|first1=Ernest|last1=Mathijs|first2=Jamie|last2=Sexton|title=Cult Cinema|year=2012|publisher=[[Wiley & Sons]]|isbn=978-1-4443-9643-0|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uPtuaV7IAt0C&pg=PT180|chapter=Exploitation and B Movies}}</ref> Academic David Andrews writes that cult softcore films are "the most masculinized, youth-oriented, populist, and openly pornographic softcore area."<ref name=andrews>{{cite book|title=Soft in the Middle: The Contemporary Softcore Feature in Its Contexts|last=Andrews|first=David|publisher=[[Ohio State University Press]]|year=2006|isbn=978-0-8142-1022-2|page=8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zk-F1B7RUfcC&pg=PT23}}</ref> The sexploitation films of [[Russ Meyer]] were among the first to abandon all hypocritical pretenses of morality and were technically proficient enough to gain a cult following. His persistent vision saw him received as an auteur worthy of academic study; director John Waters attributes this to Meyer's ability to create complicated, sexually charged films without resorting to explicit sex.<ref name=meyer />{{rp|5–7,14}} Myrna Oliver described [[Doris Wishman]]'s exploitation films as "crass, coarse, and camp ... perfect fodder for a cult following."<ref>{{cite news|last=Oliver|first=Myrna|title=Doris Wishman; Exploitation Film Director, Cult Favorite|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/aug/21/local/me-wishman21|accessdate=2013-07-29|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2002-08-21}}</ref> "Sick films", the most disturbing and graphically transgressive films, have their own distinct cult following; these films transcend their roots in exploitation, horror, and art films.<ref name=mondo>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2012|isbn=978-1-4443-9642-3|pages=105–107|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3EmSqIo4I-QC&pg=PA105|chapter=Transgression and Freakery}}</ref> In 1960s and 1970s America, exploitation and art films shared audiences and marketing, especially in New York City's [[grindhouse]] cinemas.<ref name=betz/>{{rp|219–220}}
===B and genre films=== Mathijs and Sexton state that [[film genre|genre]] is an important part of cult films; cult films will often mix, mock, or exaggerate the tropes associated with traditional genres.<ref name=mondo/> Science fiction, fantasy, and horror are known for their large and dedicated cult followings; as science fiction films become more popular, fans emphasize non-mainstream and less commercial aspects of it.<ref>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4051-7374-2|pages=205–207|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ntg-1SAKgboC&pg=PA205|chapter=Cult Science Fiction Cinema}}</ref> [[B film]]s, which are often conflated with exploitation, are as important to cult films as exploitation.<ref name=exploitation/> Teodor Reljic of ''[[Malta Today]]'' states that cult B films are a realistic goal for Malta's burgeoning film industry.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/arts/film/38734/are_cult_films_a_possibility_for_malta|title=Are 'cult' films a possibility for Malta?|last=Reljic|first=Teodor|work=[[Malta Today]]|date=2014-05-08|accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref> Genre films, B films that strictly adhere to genre limitations, can appeal to cult film fans: given their transgressive excesses, horror films are likely to become to cult films;<ref name=midnight />{{rp|33}} films like ''[[Galaxy Quest]]'' (1999) highlight the importance of cult followings and fandom to science fiction;<ref>{{cite book|last=Geraghty|first=Lincoln|title=American science fiction film and television.|year=2009|publisher=[[Berg Publishers]]|location=Oxford|isbn=978-1-84520-795-3|page=102|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=agDbWF4qJCsC&pg=PA102}}</ref> and authentic martial arts skills in [[Hong Kong action cinema|Hong Kong action films]] can drive them to become cult favorites.<ref name=hunt />{{rp|157–159}} Cult musicals can range from the traditional, such as ''[[Singin' in the Rain]]'' (1952), which appeal to cult audiences through nostalgia, camp, and spectacle, to the more non-traditional, such as ''[[Cry-Baby]]'' (1990), which parodies musicals, and ''Rocky Horror'', which uses a rock soundtrack.<ref>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2012|isbn=978-1-4443-9642-3|pages=175–177|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3EmSqIo4I-QC&pg=PA175|chapter=Cult Cinema and Music}}</ref> Romantic fairy tale ''[[The Princess Bride (film)|The Princess Bride]]'' (1987) failed to attract audiences in its original release, as the studio did not know how to market it.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ew.com/article/2011/10/07/princess-bride-reunion/|title=The Princess Bride cast, director talk inconceivable(!) cult hit|last=Rottenberg|first=Josh|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=2011-10-07|accessdate=2019-11-09}}</ref> The freedom and excitement associated with cars can be an important part of drawing cult film fans to genre films, and they can signify action and danger with more ambiguity than a gun.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/the-auto-motive-why-cars-drive-cult-movies/article11374759/|title=The auto motive: Why cars drive cult movies|last=Pevere|first=Geoff|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=2013-04-18|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> ''[[Ad Week]]'' writes that cult B films, when released on home video, market themselves and need only enough advertising to raise curiosity or nostalgia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/television/streamy-romance-americans-love-affair-b-movies-goes-digital-157724|title=Streamy Romance: Americans' Love Affair With B Movies Goes Digital|work=[[Ad Week]]|date=2014-05-21|accessdate=2014-05-29}}</ref>
===Animation=== [[Animation]] can provide wide open vistas for stories. The French film ''[[Fantastic Planet]]'' (1972) explored ideas beyond the limits of traditional, live-action science fiction films.<ref>{{cite news|last=Yagoda|first=Ben|title='Light Years' Ahead Of The Pack Animation Brings Rene Laloux's Sci-fi Vision To Life|url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-04-04/news/26253782_1_rene-laloux-light-years-david-johansen|accessdate=2013-08-01|newspaper=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=1988-04-04}}</ref> Phil Hoad of ''[[The Guardian]]'' identifies ''[[Akira (1988 film)|Akira]]'' (1988) as introducing violent, adult Japanese animation (known as [[anime]]) to the West and paving the way for later works.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hoad|first=Phil|title=Akira: the Future-Tokyo Story that Brought Anime West|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/jul/10/akira-anime-japanese-cartoon-manga|accessdate=2013-07-31|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2013-07-10}}</ref> Anime, according to academic Brian Ruh, is not a cult genre, but the lack of individual fandoms inside [[anime fandom]] itself lends itself to a bleeding over of cult attention and can help spread works internationally. Anime, which is often highly turned into series, provides its fans with alternative fictional canons and points of view that can drive fan activity. The ''[[Ghost in the Shell]]'' films, for example, provided Japanese fans with enough bonus material and spinoffs that it encouraged cult tendencies. Markets that did not support the sale of these materials saw less cult activity.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ruh|first=Brian|title=Producing Transnational Cult Media- Neon Genesis Evangelion and Ghost in the Shell in Circulation|journal=Intensities|date=Spring–Summer 2013|issue=5|url=http://intensitiescultmedia.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/producing-transnational-cult-media-neon-genesis-evangelion-and-ghost-in-the-shell-in-circulation-brian-ruh.pdf|accessdate=2013-07-30}}</ref> [[Ralph Bakshi]]'s career has been marked with controversy: ''[[Fritz the Cat (film)|Fritz the Cat]]'' (1972), the first animated film to be [[MPAA film rating system#X replaced by NC-17|rated "X" by the MPAA]], provoked outrage for its racial caricatures and graphic depictions of sex, and ''[[Coonskin (film)|Coonskin]]'' (1975) was decried as racist.<ref>{{cite news|last=Diamond|first=Jamie|title=Animation's Bad Boy Returns, Unrepentant|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/07/05/movies/film-animation-s-bad-boy-returns-unrepentant.html|accessdate=2013-07-31|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=1992-07-05}}</ref> Bakshi recalls that older animators had tired of "kid stuff" and desired edgier work, whereas younger animators hated his work for "destroying the Disney images". Eventually, his work would be reassessed and cult followings, which include [[Quentin Tarantino]] and [[Robert Rodriguez]], developed around several of his films.<ref>{{cite web|last=Huver|first=Scott|title=Animation Legend Ralph Bakshi Looks Back at His Cult Classic "Wizards"|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/blogs/popcornbiz/Ralph-Bakshis-Animated-Look-Back-at-His-Classic-Film-Wizards-142502455.html|work=[[KNTV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=2013-07-31|date=2012-05-30}}</ref> ''[[Heavy Metal (film)|Heavy Metal]]'' (1981) faced similar denunciations from critics. Donald Liebenson of the ''Los Angeles Times'' cites the violence and sexual imagery as alienating critics, who did not know what to make of the film. It would go on to become a popular midnight movie and frequently bootlegged by fans, as licensing issues kept it from being released on video for many years.<ref>{{cite news|last=Liebenson|first=Donald|title=Cult Favorite 'Heavy Metal' Once Again Making Noise|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-03-09/entertainment/ca-44792_1_heavy-metal|accessdate=2013-07-31|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1996-03-09}}</ref>
===Nonfiction=== Sensationalistic documentaries called [[mondo film]]s replicate the most shocking and transgressive elements of exploitation films. They are usually modeled after "sick films" and cover similar subject matter.<ref name=mondo/> In ''[[The Cult Film Reader]]'', academics Mathijs and Mendik write that these documentaries often present non-Western societies as "stereotypically mysterious, seductive, immoral, deceptive, barbaric or savage".<ref name=mondo2>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Mendik|first2=Xavier|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0|pages=1–10|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA10|chapter=What Is Cult Film?}}</ref> Though they can be interpreted as racist, Mathijs and Mendik state that they also "exhibit a liberal attitude towards the breaking of cultural taboos".<ref name=mondo2/> Mondo films like ''[[Faces of Death]]'' mix real and fake footage freely, and they gain their cult following through the outrage and debate over authenticity that results.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/102600/Weekend/Lifting_the_mask_from.shtml|title=Lifting the mask from 'Faces of Death'|last=Welch|first=Michael Patrick|work=[[Tampa Bay Times]]|date=2000-10-26|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> Like "so bad it's good" cult films, old propaganda and government hygiene films may be enjoyed ironically by more modern audiences for the camp value of the outdated themes and outlandish claims made about perceived social threats, such as drug use.<ref name="cult-intro"/> Academic Barry K. Grant states that [[Frank Capra]]'s ''[[Why We Fight]]'' World War II propaganda films are explicitly not cult, because they are "slickly made and have proven their ability to persuade an audience."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|editor1-last=Mathijs|editor1-first=Ernest|editor2-last=Mendik|editor2-first=Xavier|last=Grant|first=Barry K.|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0|page=78|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA78|chapter=Science Fiction Double Feature: Ideology in the Cult Film}}</ref> The [[sponsored film]] ''[[Mr. B Natural]]'' became a cult hit when it was broadcast on the satirical television show ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'';<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/arts/index.ssf/2013/03/buzz_podewell_69_longtime_dire.html|title=Buzz Podewell, 69, longtime director and acting teacher, dies|last=Mahne|first=Theodore P.|work=[[The Times-Picayune]]|date=2013-03-29|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> cast member [[Trace Beaulieu]] cited these educational shorts as his favorite to mock on the show.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/pop-culture/tv/robot-roll-call-mystery-science-theater-3000-cast-share-favorite-f2D11624170|title=Robot roll call! 'Mystery Science Theater 3000' cast share favorite episodes as show turns 25|last=Cooper|first=Gael Fashingbauer|work=[[NBC News]]|date=2013-11-24|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> Mark Jancovich states that cult audiences are drawn to these films because of their "very banality or incoherence of their political positions", unlike traditional cult films, which achieve popularity through auteurist radicalism.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|last=Jancovich|first=Mark|editor1-last=Mathijs|editor1-first=Ernest|editor2-last=Mendik|editor2-first=Xavier|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0|page=157|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA157|chapter=Cult Fictions}}</ref>
==Mainstream popularity== [[File:Quentin Tarantino by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|alt=Quentin Tarantino sitting down, smiling|Quentin Tarantino is an example of a cult film director who has achieved mainstream success.]]
Mark Shiel explains the rising popularity of cult films as an attempt by cinephiles and scholars to escape the oppressive conformity and mainstream appeal of even independent film, as well as a lack of condescension in both critics and the films;<ref name=shiel /> Academic Donna de Ville says it is a chance to subvert the dominance of academics and cinephiles.<ref name=alamo /> According to Xavier Mendik, "academics have been really interested in cult movies for quite a while now." Mendik has sought to bring together academic interest and fandom through [[Cine-Excess]], a film festival.<ref name=sheep /> I. Q. Hunter states that "it's much easier to be a cultist now, but it is also rather more inconsequential."<ref name=cineaste /> Citing the mainstream availability of ''Cannibal Holocaust'', Jeffrey Sconce rejects definitions of cult films based on controversy and excess, as they've now become meaningless.<ref name=sconce>{{cite journal|jstor=41690732|title=Cult Cinema: A Critical Symposium|last=Sconce|first=Jeffrey|work=[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]]|volume=34|issue=1|pages=48–49|date=Winter 2008}}</ref> Cult films have influenced such diverse industries as cosmetics,<ref>{{cite news|last=Stover|first=Lauren|title=A Vegan With a Dark Side|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/30/fashion/a-vegan-with-a-dark-side.html|accessdate=2013-05-30|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2013-05-29}}</ref> music videos,<ref name=borrowings /> and fashion.<ref>{{cite web|last=Collinson |first=Laura |title=Lights, Camera ... Fashion! |url=http://www.artslondonnews.co.uk/20110216_fashion-film |work=Arts London News |publisher=[[London College of Communication]] |accessdate=2013-06-03 |date=2011-02-17 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140420073219/http://www.artslondonnews.co.uk/20110216_fashion-film |archivedate=April 20, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref> Cult films have shown up in less expected places; as a sign of his popularity, a bronze statue of [[Ed Wood]] has been proposed in his hometown,<ref>{{cite news|last=Musso|first=Anthony P.|title=Cult Figure Wood May Get Statue in His Honor|work=[[Poughkeepsie Journal]]|url=http://www.poughkeepsiejournal.com/article/20130529/NEWS01/305290018?nclick_check=1|accessdate=2013-05-30|date=2013-05-29}}</ref> and ''[[L'Osservatore Romano]]'', the official newspaper of the [[Holy See]], has courted controversy for its endorsement of cult films and pop culture.<ref>{{cite news|last=Squires|first=Nick|title=Vatican Declares the Blues Brothers a 'Catholic Classic'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/7835639/Vatican-declares-the-Blues-Brothers-a-Catholic-classic.html|accessdate=2013-05-31|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2010-06-18}}</ref> When cities attempt to renovate neighborhoods, fans have called attempts to demolish iconic settings from cult films "cultural vandalism".<ref>{{cite news|last=Herbert|first=Ian|title=Fans of Cult Film Campaign to Save Car Park|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/fans-of-cult-film-campaign-to-save-car-park-710061.html|accessdate=2013-05-31|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2000-07-20}}</ref> Cult films can also drive tourism,<ref>{{cite news|title=Cult Film Still Reels in Tourists |url=http://www.omaha.com/article/20091025/LIVING/710259921 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130616013259/http://www.omaha.com/article/20091025/LIVING/710259921 |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 16, 2013 |accessdate=2013-05-31 |newspaper=[[The Omaha World Herald]] |date=2009-10-25 |agency=[[Associated Press]] }}</ref> even when it is unwanted.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fiore|first=Faye|title=Cult Film 'Blair Witch' Was Tourist Horror Show for Small Town|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/travel/2012030605_weblairwitch04.html|accessdate=2013-05-31|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=2010-06-06}}</ref>
As far back as the 1970s, ''[[Attack of the Killer Tomatoes]]'' (1978) was designed specifically to be a cult film,<ref>{{cite web|last=Firsching|first=Robert|title=Attack of the Killer Tomatoes!|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/v3267|work=[[Allmovie]]|publisher=[[Rovi]]|accessdate=2013-05-01}}</ref> and ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' was produced by [[20th Century Fox]], a major Hollywood studio. Over its decades-long release, ''Rocky Horror'' became the seventh highest grossing R-rated film when adjusted for inflation;<ref>{{cite web|title=The Rocky Horror Picture Show|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=rockyhorrorpictureshow.htm|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2013-05-01}}</ref> Journalist Matt Singer has questioned whether ''Rocky Horror''{{'}}s popularity invalidates its cult status.<ref>{{cite web| last1=Hillis| first1=Aaron| last2=Orange| first2=Michelle| last3=Singer| first3=Matt| last4=Sweeney| first4=R. Emmet| last5=Willmore| first5=Alison| title=Gagging on the Kool-Aid: Cult Films We Just Don't Get| url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2007/01/gagging-on-the-koolaid-cult-fi|work=[[IFC (American TV channel)|IFC]]| accessdate=2013-05-16|date=2007-01-15}}</ref> Founded in 1974, [[Troma Entertainment]], an independent studio, would become known for both its cult following and cult films.<ref>{{cite book|last=McKendry|first=Rebekah|title=Cinema Inferno: Celluloid Explosions from the Cultural Margins|year=2010|publisher=[[Scarecrow Press]]|location=Lanham|isbn=978-0-8108-7657-6|page=164|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4aSF_sChKG0C&pg=PA164|editor1-last=Weiner|editor1-first=Robert G.|editor2-last=Cline|editor2-first=John|chapter=Chapter 9: Troma Entertainment}}</ref> In the 1980s, [[Danny Peary]]'s ''[[Cult Movies (book)|Cult Movies]]'' (1981) would influence director [[Edgar Wright]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Alter|first=Ethan|title=Pilgrim's Progress: Cult director Edgar Wright Guides Michael Cera in Genre-Bending Comic Romp|url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/content_display/news-and-features/features/movies/e3ic2e2d16144df098a1f2524c1df7af988|work=[[Film Journal International]]|accessdate=2013-05-01|date=2010-07-20}}</ref> and film critic Scott Tobias of ''[[The A.V. Club]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tobias|first=Scott|title=The New Cult Canon: An Introduction|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/the-new-cult-canon-an-introduction-9808|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=2013-05-01|date=2008-02-21}}</ref> The rise of home video would have a mainstreaming effect on cult films and cultish behavior, though some collectors would be unlikely to self-identify as cult film fans.<ref name=cineaste /> Film critic [[Joe Bob Briggs]] began reviewing [[drive-in theater]] and cult films, though he faced much criticism as an early advocate of [[exploitation film|exploitation]] and cult films. Briggs highlights the mainstreaming of cult films by pointing out the respectful obituaries that cult directors have received from formerly hostile publications and acceptance of politically incorrect films at mainstream film festivals.<ref name=joebob /> This acceptance is not universal, though, and some critics have resisted this mainstreaming of paracinema.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hawkins|first=Joan|title=Culture Wars: Some New Trends in Art Horror|journal=[[Jump Cut (journal)|Jump Cut]]|year=2009|issue=51|url=http://www.ejumpcut.org/archive/jc51.2009/artHorror/text.html|accessdate=2013-06-22}}</ref> Beginning in the 1990s, director [[Quentin Tarantino]] would have the greatest success in turning cult films mainstream.<ref name="not-cult" /><ref name="who-killed">{{cite news|last=Leigh|first=Danny|title=Who Killed Cult Movies?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2009/oct/13/who-killed-cult-movies|accessdate=2013-05-01|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2009-10-13}}</ref> Tarantino later used his fame to champion obscure cult films that had influenced him and set up the short-lived [[Rolling Thunder Pictures]], which distributed several of his favorite cult films.<ref>{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=John|title=Quentin Tarantino: Champion of Trash Cinema|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/aug/17/quentin-tarantino-trash-cinema|accessdate=2013-05-01|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2009-08-17}}</ref> Tarantino's clout led Phil Hoad of ''[[The Guardian]]'' to call Tarantino the world's most influential director.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hoad|first=Phil|title=Is Quentin Tarantino the World's Most Influential Director?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2013/jan/15/quentin-tarantino-most-influential-director|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2013-05-16|date=2013-01-15}}</ref>
As major Hollywood studios and audiences both become savvy to cult films, productions once limited to cult appeal have instead become popular hits, and cult directors have become hot properties known for more mainstream and accessible films.<ref name=metro /> Remarking on the popular trend of remaking cult films, Claude Brodesser-Akner of ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine states that Hollywood studios have been superstitiously hoping to recreate past successes rather than trading on nostalgia.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brodesser-Akner|first=Claude|title=Why Do Studios Think There's So Much Value in Old Titles?| url=http://www.vulture.com/2011/08/conan_the_barbarian_fright_nig.html| work=Vulture| publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]| accessdate=2013-05-31| date=2011-08-19}}</ref> Their popularity would bring some critics to proclaim the death of cult films now that they have finally become successful and mainstream,<ref name="who-killed" /> are too slick to attract a proper cult following,<ref name="cult-dead" /> lack context,<ref name=sconce /> or are too easily found online.<ref>{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Brandon|title=The Internet and the Cult Film: On A Fan's Notes|url=http://filmmakermagazine.com/65996-the-internet-and-the-cult-film-on-a-fans-notes/|work=Filmmaker|accessdate=2013-05-13|date=2013-04-04}}</ref> In response, David Church says that cult film fans have retreated to more obscure and difficult to find films, often using illegal distribution methods, which preserves the outlaw status of cult films. Virtual spaces, such as online forums and fan sites, replace the traditional [[fanzine]]s and newsletters.<ref name=cineaste /> Cult film fans consider themselves collectors, rather than consumers, as they associate consumers with mainstream, Hollywood audiences.<ref name=hollows />{{rp|46}} This collecting can take the place of fetishization of a single film.<ref name=sconce /> Addressing concerns that DVDs have revoked the cult status of films like ''Rocky Horror'', academic Mikel J. Koven states that small scale screenings with friends and family can replace midnight showings. Koven also identifies television shows, such as ''[[Twin Peaks]]'', as retaining more traditional cult activities inside popular culture.<ref name=cineaste /> [[David Lynch]] himself has not ruled out another television series, as studios have become reluctant to take chances on non-mainstream ideas.<ref>{{cite news|last=Walker|first=Tim|title=Waxing Lyrical: David Lynch on His New Passion - and Why He May Never Make Another Movie|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/waxing-lyrical-david-lynch-on-his-new-passion--and-why-he-may-never-make-another-movie-8665457.html|accessdate=2013-06-28|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2013-06-23}}</ref> Despite this, the [[Alamo Drafthouse]] has capitalized on cult films and the surrounding culture through inspiration drawn from ''Rocky Horror'' and retro promotional gimmickry. They sell out their shows regularly and have acquired a cult following of their own.<ref name=alamo />
Academic Bob Batchelor, writing in ''Cult Pop Culture'', states that the internet has democratized cult culture and destroyed the line between cult and mainstream. Fans of even the most obscure films can communicate online with each other in vibrant communities.<ref>{{cite book|last=Batchelor|first=Bob|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream: How the Fringe Became Mainstream, Volume 1|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35781-7|pages=xii-xiii|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jqd92sX1hAoC&pg=PR12|chapter=Introduction}}</ref> Although known for their big-budget [[blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbusters]], [[Steven Spielberg]] and [[George Lucas]] have criticized the current Hollywood system of gambling everything on the opening weekend of these productions. Geoffrey Macnab of ''[[The Independent]]'' instead suggests that Hollywood look to capitalize on cult films, which have exploded in popularity on the internet.<ref>{{cite news|last=Macnab|first=Geoffrey|title=Cult Classics Take on the Blockbusters as Audiences Switch on to Internet Downloads|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/cult-classics-take-on-the-blockbusters-as-audiences-switch-on-to-internet-downloads-877798.html|accessdate=2013-05-09|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2008-07-26}}</ref> The rise of [[social media]] has been a boon to cult films. Sites such as [[Twitter]] have displaced traditional venues for fandom and courted controversy from cultural critics who are unamused by campy cult films.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Crouch|first=Ian|title=We Watched "Sharknado"|journal=[[The New Yorker]]|date=2013-07-12|url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/we-watched-sharknado|accessdate=2013-07-16}}</ref> After a clip from one of his films went [[viral video|viral]], director-producer [[Roger Corman]] made a distribution deal with [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Nakashima|first=Ryan|title=For new YouTube, You Pay|url=http://www.sfltimes.com/soflo-live/entertainment/for-new-youtube-you-pay|accessdate=2013-05-22|newspaper=South Florida Times|date=2013-05-22|agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref> [[Found footage (appropriation)|Found footage]] which had originally been distributed as cult VHS collections eventually went viral on YouTube, which opened them to new generations of fans.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Iain Robert|title=Collecting the Trash: The Cult of the Ephemeral Clip from VHS to YouTube|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2011-09-16|volume=14|issue=8|url=http://flowtv.org/2011/09/collecting-the-trash/|accessdate=2013-06-21}}</ref> Films such as ''[[Birdemic]]'' (2008) and ''[[The Room (film)|The Room]]'' (2003) gained quick, massive popularity, as prominent members of social networking sites discussed them. Their rise as "instant cult classics" bypasses the years of obscurity that most cult films labor under.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lemire |first=Christy |title=Schlockey Films Gain Instant Cult Status via Net |url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/tech/D9FI2T4G0.htm |accessdate=2013-05-11 |newspaper=[[Business Week]] |date=2010-05-07 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120122004/http://www.businessweek.com/ap/tech/D9FI2T4G0.htm |archivedate=November 20, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref> In response, critics have described the use of [[viral marketing]] as [[astroturfing]] and an attempt to manufacture cult films.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Chris|title=How to Build a Nerd Film Cult|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/jun/26/entertainment/et-lee26|accessdate=2013-05-13|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2004-06-26}}</ref>
I. Q. Hunter identifies a prefabricated cult film style which includes "deliberately, insulting bad films", "slick exercises in dysfunction and alienation", and mainstream films "that sell themselves as worth obsessing over".<ref name=cineaste /> Writing for [[NPR]], Scott Tobias states that [[Don Coscarelli]], whose previous films effortlessly attracted cult followings, has drifted into this realm. Tobias criticizes Coscarelli as trying too hard to appeal to cult audiences and sacrificing internal consistency for calculated quirkiness.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tobias|first=Scott|title=Spoiler Alert: 'John Dies,' But The Rest? Who Can Tell?|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/01/24/170011522/spoiler-alert-john-dies-but-the-rest-who-can-tell|accessdate=2013-06-23|newspaper=[[National Public Radio]]|date=2013-01-24}}</ref> Influenced by the successful online hype of ''[[The Blair Witch Project]]'' (1999), other films have attempted to draw online cult fandom with the use of prefabricated cult appeal. ''[[Snakes on a Plane]]'' (2006) is an example that attracted massive attention from curious fans. Uniquely, its cult following preceded the film's release and included speculative parodies of what fans imagined the film might be. This reached the point of [[technological convergence#Convergence culture|convergence culture]] when fan speculation began to impact on the film's production.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stevens|first=Kirsten|editor1-last=Cash|editor1-first=Conall|editor2-last=Snow|editor2-first=Samuel Cuff|title=Snakes on a Plane and the Prefabricated Cult Film|journal=Colloquy|year=2009|issue=18|url=http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/colloquy/download/colloquy_issue_eighteen/stevens.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-23|publisher=[[Monash University]]}}</ref> Although it was proclaimed a cult film and major game-changer before it was released,<ref>{{cite news|last=Chonin|first=Neva|title='Snakes on a Plane' Blog Buzz Forces Hollywood into Overdue Attitude Adjustment|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Snakes-on-a-Plane-blog-buzz-forces-Hollywood-2533141.php|accessdate=2013-05-13|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=2006-06-12}}</ref> it failed to win either mainstream audiences or maintain its cult following. In retrospect, critic Spencer Kornhaber would call it a serendipitous novelty and a footnote to a "more naive era of the Internet".<ref>{{cite news|last=Kornhaber|first=Spencer|title='Snakes on a Plane,' 5 Years Later|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2011/08/snakes-on-a-plane-5-years-later/243790/|accessdate=2013-05-13|newspaper=[[The Atlantic]]|date=2011-08-18}}</ref> However, it became influential in both marketing<ref>{{cite web|last=Carle|first=Chris|title=Snakes on a Plane|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/01/02/snakes-on-a-plane|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=2013-05-13|date=2007-01-02}}</ref> and titling.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Suddath|first=Claire|title=Cowboys, Aliens, Snakes and Sharks: In Praise of Literal Movie Titles|url=http://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,2086635,00.html|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=2013-05-13|date=2011-08-04}}</ref> This trend of "instant cult classics" which are hailed yet fail to attain a lasting following is described by Matt Singer, who states that the phrase is an oxymoron.<ref name="kool-aid">{{cite web|last=Singer|first=Matt|title=Pass the Kool-Aid: Five Flicks That Aspired To Cult Status|url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2008/11/pass-the-koolaid-five-movies-t|work=[[IFC (American TV channel)|IFC]]|accessdate=2013-05-20|date=2008-11-06}}</ref>
Cult films are often approached in terms of [[auteur theory]], which states that the director's creative vision drives a film. This has fallen out of favor in academia, creating a disconnect between cult film fans and critics.<ref name=hutchings />{{rp|135}} Matt Hills states that auteur theory can help to create cult films; fans that see a film as continuing a director's creative vision are likely to accept it as cult.<ref name=cineaste /> According to academic Greg Taylor, auteur theory also helped to popularize cult films when middlebrow audiences found an accessible way to approach avant-garde film criticism. Auteur theory provided an alternative culture for cult film fans while carrying the weight of scholarship. By requiring repeated viewings and extensive knowledge of details, auteur theory naturally appealed to cult film fans. Taylor further states that this was instrumental in allowing cult films to break through to the mainstream.<ref>{{cite book|last=Taylor|first=Greg|title=Artists in the Audience: Cults, Camp, and American Film Criticism|year=2001|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|isbn=978-0-691-08955-3|pages=87–88|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fukKSOOc0dYC&pg=PA87}}</ref> Academic Joe Tompkins states that this auteurism is often highlighted when mainstream success occurs. This may take the place of – and even ignore – political readings of the director. Cult films and directors may be celebrated for their transgressive content, daring, and independence, but Tompkins argues that mainstream recognition requires they be palatable to corporate interests who stand to gain much from the mainstreaming of cult film culture. While critics may champion revolutionary aspects of filmmaking and political interpretation, Hollywood studios and other corporate interests will instead highlight only the aspects that they wish to legitimize in their own films, such as sensational exploitation. Someone like [[George Romero]], whose films are both transgressive and subversive, will have the transgressive aspects highlighted while the subversive aspects are ignored.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tompkins|first=Joe|title="They Have the Oscars": Oppositional Telebranding and the Cult of the Horror Auteur|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2010-07-16|volume=12|issue=4|url=http://flowtv.org/2010/07/oppositional-telebranding-and-the-cult-of-the-horror-auteur/|accessdate=2013-06-21}}</ref>
